awd_titl_txt: CDS&E: Collaborative Research: CDS&E: Advances in closure modeling for turbulent flows with finite-sized particles informed by massive simulations on heterogeneous architectures
awd_abstract_narration:
Suspensions of solid particles immersed in a fluid – either gas or liquid – are important in many industrial systems and in many natural processes.  Multiphase computational fluid dynamics to predict the behavior of these systems relies on making approximations to the appropriate equations.  As a result, some important phenomena, such as the aggregation of solid particles in the flow, are not accurately predicted.  The formation of particle clusters in gas-solid flows results from complex interactions of the particles with the gas and the particles with each other.  This collaborative Computational and Data-Enabled Science and Engineering (CDS&E) project will develop a modeling framework for particle clustering in gas-flow problems enabled by massive simulations using highly scalable codes.  Numerical techniques developed by the researchers at the three participating institutions will be integrated to formulate a consistent and scalable framework for solving problems in which particle clustering is significant.  The results will enable researchers to tackle problems involving particle clusters such as chemical looping combustion, biomass fast pyrolysis and carbon dioxide capture applications.  Computational data generated in the project will be available to researchers through a web-based interface.  The researchers will use the project to develop educational tools to engage a broad public audience, especially middle and high school students, in displays of the fundamental principles underlying flows of particle suspensions in a gas.

Particle-resolved Direct Numerical Simulation (PR-DNS), which can resolve microscale particle-fluid interactions and point-particle direct numeric simulation (PP-DNS), which can model inter-particle collisions, will be integrated with pseudo-spectral techniques, which have the potential to accelerate computations for gas-solid flows.  Highly scalable PR–DNS and PP-DNS codes will be developed to leverage new algorithmic advances in (a) turbulence simulation using the pseudo-spectral approach on heterogeneous architectures and (b) efficient scaling with number of particles in Eulerian-Lagrangian multiphase flow solvers to perform massive PR–DNS and PP-DNS of canonical clustering flows on scales needed to demonstrate particle clustering.  Consistent scalable closures will be developed for volume-filtered Eulerian-Lagrangian formulations and PP-DNS and PR-DNS.   A consistent averaging operation will be applied on the PR–DNS data that explicitly takes the resolved scales into account, resulting in new unclosed terms that have yet to be quantified in a two-phase context. Novel closure techniques using machine learning will be employed to evaluate the functional form of the new terms.  To maximize their impact on model development, the source codes and canonical multiphase flow data generated in this project will be archived in an open-access database available to the broader scientific community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Suspensions of solid particles in fluids (liquid or gas) arise in many natural and engineered systems that impact several aspects of human life, such as health, safety and security, and the sustained availability of energy. Simulating realistic particle-laden flow systems requires cutting-edge computational resources that can perform ultrafast computational operations on massive amounts of data that arise from representing the finest flow details such as flow around each individual particles in industrial devices or natural systems with trillions of particles. One approach developed by University of Michigan (U-M) to make the simulation of very large systems amenable to computation is to smooth out the finest details while approximating the essential interactions of particles with the flow. Researchers at Iowa State University (ISU) have focused on developing theoretical and modeling tools that are able to further simplify and speed up such computations by identifying key signatures of particle clustering that can be computed from simulations performed by U-M, and whose evolution can represent the behavior of complex turbulent particle-laden flow. By analyzing high-fidelity simulations of turbulent particle-laden flow performed by the research team at Georgia Tech, ISU researchers have also collaboratively explored how the history of a particle's interaction with a turbulent flow plays an important role in its clustering behavior.

One method of simulating particle-laden flows with very large numbers of small particles proposed by U-M is to evolve a continuum average of the particle phase. This is done by taking some notion of an average of the disperse phase, be it a smoothing operation (see Figure 1) or a probabilistic expectation over a number of realizations. In practice, all models of this type are only valid in certain fluid regimes (such as dilute/dense, high/low velocity difference between phases). We developed a formulation that unifies these two notions of an average. Two approaches were used to generate relevant statistics, the first utilizing a high-efficiency approach for computing statistics on frozen data sets, and the latter utilizing a method for collecting statistics of simulations for a wide range of flow conditions without storage of data. Storing statistics but not the source data allows for far more samples, as the statistics are much smaller than the source data. In addition, an experiment was designed in which a triply-periodic cube of turbulent flow, necessitating a forcing scheme to counter the decrease in kinetic energy through viscosity, was used as an inflow condition for a crossflow, without such forcing (see Figure 2). This experiment has two primary benefits. First, it removes the need for forcing within the observed parts of the flow, thus allowing for a true observation of turbulence evolved by physically valid governing equations. Second, it is similar in setup to wind tunnels with grid generated turbulence, which we intend to compare to in the future. The code used for numerical simulation in this project have been made open-source, and may be leveraged by other researchers for their own numerical studies of particle-laden turbulence.
